children.name: close a1
children.definition: close/shuta2 to become shut:đónglại
examples: he walked out and the door shut behind him.
there was a bang as the gates shut.
her eyes closed, and she fell into a deep sleep.

children.name: slam b2
children.definition: slamalsoslam shut if a doorslamsorslams shut, it shuts quickly and makes a loud noise: đóng sập lại
examples: ▪ outside in the street, car doors slammed and people were shouting.
▪ she heard a door slam shut and the sound of footsteps on the path.

children.name: slide shut b1
children.definition: slide/blow/swing etc shut if a door, window, gate etc slides, blows, swings etc shut, it shuts by sliding, being blown, swinging etc:tự đóng lại do lung lay
examples: the window suddenly blew shut, with a loud bang.
the elevator doors silently slid shut.

children.name: to close an area, entrance or opening
close off c1
children.definition: close off to put sth across the entrance of a place to stop people from entering
examples: police quickly closed off the area.

children.name: block up x
children.definition: block up to put sth into a hole or entrance so that it is permanently closed: khóa lại , đóng lại, bịt lại, che lại
examples: ▪ martha tried to block the mouse holes up, but new ones kept appearing
▪ some of the windows in the church had been blocked up.
▪ he blocked up the entrance to the tunnel with stones.

children.name: plug x
children.definition: plug to fill a hole with a piece of suitable material in order to stop a liquid from getting through:bịt lại
examples: we tried to plug the hole in the bottom of the boat with a plastic bag.
have you plugged that leak(= stopped it by filling the hole)in the pipe?
my nose was bleeding and i plugged it with cotton wool.
plug up
they didn’t have enough material to plug up the gaps around the pipe.

children.name: seal c2
children.definition: seal
examples: 1(alsoseal up) to close an entrance or a container with something that stops air, water etc from coming in or out of it : đóng kín, bịt kín, gắn xi
the window was sealed shut.
seal a joint/crack/opening/gap
a quick way to seal awkward gaps is to use a foam filler.
dried milk is kept inhermetically sealed(= very tightly closed )containers.
2to close an envelope, package etc by using sth sticky to hold its edges in place : đóng kín,niêm phong
he wrote the address and sealed the envelope.
seal the package (up) with sticky tape.
he sealed (down) the envelope and put a stamp on it.

children.name: seal off c2
children.definition: seal off to prevent people from entering an area or building, often because it is dangerous :cô lập,phong tỏa,niêm phong
examples: two more bombs have been discovered since the police sealed off the area.

children.name: block off x
children.definition: block off to close a road, path, or entrance so that people cannot use it: phong tỏa, cô lập
examples: all the roads out of the town had been blocked off by the police.
police blocked off the city centre streets.
the fireplace had been blocked off.

children.name: to close a container: bottle, can, jar, etc
close a1
children.definition: shut/closea2  to close a container, such as a box, case, or bottle:đóng lại
examples: ▪ as the teacher appeared, matt shut the box quickly.
▪ russell shut his briefcase with a snap, and the meeting was over.
▪ put lids on all the jars and close them tightly.

children.name: put the lid on b2
children.definition: put the lid on to shut a container such as a bottle or box by putting a lid onto it: đóng nắp
examples: ▪ put the lid on the cookie jar when you’ve finished with it!
▪ if you leave cooked food in a pan, you should always put the lid on.

children.name: screw on x
children.definition: screw on/ˌskruː ˈɒn/  to shut a container such as a bottle by putting the lid on and turning it round and round until it cannot be turned any more: đóng nắp chặt
examples: screw on something: đóng nắp chặt lại
▪ i screwed on the top of the bottle as tightly as i could.
screw something back on: đóng chặt lại trên cái gì
▪ the fuel tank cap hadn’t been screwed back on properly, and it came off when i drove away.
screw something on: đóng nắp chặt lại
▪ she screwed the lid of the jar on again.

children.name: open a1
children.definition: open/ˈəʊpən/  mở ra( cửa)
examples: ▪ the train doors open and close automatically.
▪ the door slowly opened and a small boy entered the room.
▪ after a short discussion with the customs officers, the gates opened and the truck moved off.

children.name: burst open b2
children.definition: burst/fly open to open very suddenly - used especially in stories or descriptions: mở tung ra
examples: ▪ before mr carey could speak, the door burst open and mr watson rushed into the room.
▪ every time we go round a corner, the passenger door flies open.

children.name: to close a door, window, box etc
shut a2
children.definition: shut/ʃʌt/  to move a door, window, gate etc so that it is no longer open: đóng lại
examples: ▪ come in and shut the door behind you.
▪ someone had shut the gate to stop the sheep getting out onto the road.
▪ she heard charlotte downstairs shutting the windows, and locking up for the night.

children.name: close a1
children.definition: close/kləʊz/  to shut something,especially in a careful way:đóng lại
examples: ▪ do you mind if i close the window?
▪ she took the necklace out of the box and closed the lid.

children.name: slam b2
children.definition: slam/slæm/  to shut a door quickly so that it makes a loud noise, especially because you are angry: đóng sập cửa
examples: ▪ jane marched out of the room slamming the door behind her.
▪ he slammed the door so hard that the glass cracked.

children.name: push sth shut b1
children.definition: push/kick/slide etc something shut/ˌpʊʃ something ˈʃʌt/  to push, kick, slide etc something so that it shuts:đẩy sập cái gì
examples: ▪ the woman pushed the door shut with her foot.
▪ it started raining, so i quickly pulled the window shut.
▪ ‘sorry, we’re closed,’ said the official, sliding the wooden panel shut.

children.name: push the door to u
children.definition: pull/push the door to to move a door so that it is almost shut: đẩy cửa lại, khép cửa lại
examples: ▪ ‘tell me what’s wrong,’ i said, pulling the door to.
▪ she pushed the door to against the blinding sunlight.

children.name: draw the curtains x
children.definition: draw the curtains/close the curtains/ˌdrɔː ðə ˈkɜːʳtnz, ˌkləʊz ðə ˈkɜːʳtnz/  to close curtains by pulling them across a window: đóng màn, khép màn
examples: ▪ let’s draw the curtains. we don’t want people looking in.
▪ the curtains were closed and the room was in darkness.

children.name: to open a door, window, box etc
open a1
children.definition: open/ˈəʊpən/  mở
examples: ▪ it’s very hot in here. do you mind if i open the window
▪ the drawer’s locked - you need a key to open it.
open something wide
▪ he opened the door wide, and gestured for me to come in.
open upspoken use this to tell someone to open a door:: mở ra
▪ open up - it’s the police

children.name: unlock b2
children.definition: unlock/ʌnˈlɒkǁ-ˈlɑːk/  to turn the a key in the lock on a door, drawer, cupboard etc so that you can open it: mở khóa
examples: ▪ unlock the door! we can’t get out!
▪ which of these keys unlocks the safe?
▪ ‘come and see’, jo said, unlocking a huge iron gate.

children.name: force open x
children.definition: force open to open a drawer, window, cupboard etc by using force, often with a tool: phá cửa
examples: force sth/it open
▪ the door’s stuck - we’ll have to force it open.
force open sth
▪ the burglars had forced open the window with an iron bar.
▪ it looked as though the shed had been forced open.

children.name: break down u
children.definition: break down to completely break a locked door in order to get into a room or building: đập vỡ , đập tan
examples: ▪ firemen had to break the door down.
▪ open the door now or we’ll break it down!

children.name: wind down x
children.definition: wind down/roll downuk  to open a car window, especially by turning a handle: hạ ( cửa sổ xe hơi )
examples: ▪ the driver wound down his window and asked us the way to the stadium.
▪ mom, will you roll your window down a little please?

children.name: prise open x
children.definition: prise openuk /pryopenus  to open sth by forcing one part of it away from the other part, using a tool: mở
examples: ▪ all the flats were boarded up, but we managed to prise a few boards open.
▪ laura leaned forward to pry open the crate.
prise the lid offremove the lid to open it: mở
▪ i picked up the coffee tin and, using a knife, prised the lid off.

children.name: try u
children.definition: try/traɪ/  to try to open a door or window in order to see if it is locked: cố gắng mở khóa
examples: ▪ i knocked, then tried the door. it was open, but the room was empty.
▪ i went around the back to try the windows, but they were all locked.

children.name: to close your eyes or mouth
close a1
children.definition: close to close your eyes or mouth:đóng
examples: ▪ i lay down and closed my eyes.
▪ lara opened her mouth to speak, then closed it again.

children.name: shut a2
children.definition: shut to close your eyes or mouth:đóng
examples: ▪ he shut his eyes and listened to the music.

children.name: to open a packet or sth that is folded or rolled
open a2
children.definition: open/ˈəʊpən/  mở(
examples: ▪ aren’t you going to open your letter?
bạn đang mở thư hả?
▪ judy opened another pack of cigarettes.
judy mở một hộp thuốc lá khác
▪ when i received the parcel, it had already been opened.
khi tôi nhận được cái bưu kiện, nó đã mở rồi

children.name: unwrap x
children.definition: unwrap to open a package by removing the paper that is wrapped around it:
examples: ▪ i just love unwrapping christmas presents!
▪ sarah sat down and unwrapped her sandwiches.

children.name: unfold c1
children.definition: unfold/ʌnˈfəʊld/  to open something that was folded, such as a piece of paper or cloth:
examples: ▪ they unfolded the tablecloth and set out the picnic.
▪ the receipt had been folded and unfolded so many times that it was almost in pieces.

children.name: unroll x
children.definition: unroll/ʌnˈrəʊl/  to spread out something that was rolled up, so that it lies flat:
examples: ▪ he unrolled the map and spread it on the table.
▪ while we were admiring the rugs, the shopkeeper started to unroll a splendid carpet.

children.name: unwind c2
children.definition: unwind to undo sth that has been wrapped around sth else, or to become undone after being wrapped around sth : tháo ra, gỡ ra
examples: she started to unwind her scarf.
in a nearby medical tent, ausarmy doctor gently unwinds metruk's bandage.

children.name: to open a container: bottle, can, jar, etc
open a2
children.definition: open/ˈəʊpən/  to open a bottle, box, or other container by removing or lifting its top or lid: mở( chai, hộp)
examples: ▪ ask the waiter to open another bottle of champagne.
▪ a little gadget that helps you to open jars

children.name: unscrew x
children.definition: unscrew/ʌnˈskruː/  to remove the top or lid of a bottle or container by turning it: vặn, tháo ( lắp chai lọ )
examples: ▪ robyn unscrewed a jar of moisturiser and smoothed it over her face.
▪ pills are stored in containers with tops that are difficult for children to unscrew.

children.name: crack open x
children.definition: crack open to open a bottle of alcohol: mở, khui
examples: ▪ let’s crack open a bottle of champagne.
▪ we cracked a few cans of beer open and sat down to watch the game.

children.name: uncork x
children.definition: uncork to open a bottle of wine by removing the cork. the cork is a piece of wood which is put in the top of the bottle:mở nút, tháo nút bần
examples: ray uncorked the bottle and offered me a glass of wine.

children.name: to open your eyes or mouth
open a1
children.definition: open your eyes/mouth mở mắt/ miệng
examples: she opened her eyes and sat up in bed.
open (your mouth) wide
the dentist told me to open my mouth a little wider.
open wide. i need to look at the back of your throat.
